div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Extravagant Rumor from Kentucky.
div3.p:
A gentleman who left Knoxville Sunday evening says it was reported there that the Kentucky Legislature had passed, by a majority of five to one, an ordinance of secession from the Abolition Union.
He further states that as soon as this decision was announced the Legislative Hall was surrounded by a regiment of Pennsylvania soldiers, and every member of the body arrested.
It is hardly likely that there is any truth in either of the reports.

div3.head: Promotions.
div3.p:
Brig. Gen. Jubal A. Early has been made a Major General, and placed in command of Ewell's old division.
Brig. Gen. Trimble has been made a Major General, and placed over Jackson's old division.

div3.head: The naval engagement at Galveston.
div3.p:
Our Galveston correspondent, yesterday, gave a very interesting account of the land operations at the re-capture of that city.
The Houston Telegraph gives an excellent description of the naval engagement.
The Bayou City, a Houston and Galveston packet, had been taken by the State and fitted up as a gunboat, under charge of Capt. Henry Lubbock.
She was armed with a 31 pounder rifled gun on her bow deck.
Bulwarks of cotton bales were built up on her sides, and a force of a hundred men put on board of her. The Neptune, another Bayou packet, was taken on the 16th, and, under direction of Major Leon Smith, fitted up as a gunboat as well as it could be done in the brief time.
Bulwarks of cotton bales were built up also on her guards, and she had much the appearance, when she left Houston, of a well loaded cotton boat, taking her cargo down to Galveston for shipment.
She was armed with two howitzer guns.
Sharpshooters, detailed from Texas cavalry regiments, were on both boats.--The vessels laid at Half-Moon Shoals, 15 miles from Galveston, awaiting the signal from shore to go up and join in the attack.
The Telegraph says:

q.p:
They waited till the moon went down, a little after 4 o'clock, anxiously listening for the report of the guns.
Half an hour after the flashes from the shore batteries announced the beginning of the fight.
Major Smith immediately ordered a return to Galveston, to use his own words, "with all the steam we could crack on," remarking, "We must get there as quick as we can and attack them."--Firing up with rosin, they immediately put back, the Bayou City in advances, the Neptune and John F. Carr following.
At dawn of day the Harriet Lane was discovered, and when within about half a mile the Bayou City opened fire on her with the 32 pound rifled gun while she was engaged with the shore batteries.
Several shots were fired, the second striking her plumb behind the wheel, knocking a hole in her big enough for a man to crawl through.
Capt. Weir, commanding the gun, was requested by a spectator to give them a New Year's present from him. As he did so, Captain Weir cried out, "Well, here goes your New Year's present," and the gun exploded killing him instantly and wounding Captain Schneider and one or two others.

div3.p:
The Harriet Lane was lying at anchor, with steam on, swinging with a strong ebb tide, bow to the west.
I was instructed, says Capt. McCormick, the pilot, to endeavor to so hit her as to allow the men a chance to board.
Going with a strong ebb tide I dare not run against her bow, so I endeavored to strike forward of the larboard wheel house.
Owing to the position of the Lane and the strength of the tide I missed my aim, struck a glancing blow, and passed by. The wheelhouse and upper works of the Harriet Lane being very strong, tore off the outside planking of the Bayou City's larboard wheelhouse and side.
Capt. Lubbock ordered me to get around as soon as possible, and make at her again, the boat having nothing to depend upon but her sharpshooters and her qualities as a ram.

Meantime the Neptune came up, striking the Harriet Lane on the starboard side, getting her bow stove in, and causing her to leak badly.
She then passed round under the stern of the Lane, receiving her shots as she passed.
One of the shots of the Lane struck the Neptune's hull, causing her to take water last.
She got on the edge of the channel, and soon sunk in eight feet-water.

By this time the Bayou City had rounded to with head up stream, and run into the Harriet Lane, striking her fairly all of the larboard wheel-house, and running her bow so far under the gunwale and wheel that she could not be extricated, and the two vessels stuck fact together.
As soon as we struck the order to board was given, which was immediately obeyed--Major Smith, owing to his experience as a sailor, being the first man on board.
Many of the boys failed in climbing the netting, and could not get over until they had cut it away, which was soon done.
As soon as our men appeared on the Harriet Lane her crew deserted the dock and took to the hold.
It was soon made known by some officer on board that the ship surrendered, and the crew asked to be received and treated as prisoners of war.

For some time after the Harriet Lane surrendered, the other vessels continued to fire, directing their fire at the Lane, the Bayou City, and the Neptune, although the latter had settled to the bottom.
The Owasso came up to within two or three hundred yards and fired several shots.
An effort was made to turn the Lane's guns on her, but she was so listed by the pressure of the Bayou City under her gunwale that they could not be worked.
Capt. Lubbock then suggested to Major Smith that it would be well to make the officer who delivered up the ship run up the white flag, which was done.
Capt. Lubbock then went with a flag of truce to the Clifton and Owasso, the latter having retired and joined the Clifton.
An interview was had with Capt.
Law, of the Clifton, and an immediate surrender of the fleet demanded by Capt. Lubbock, in the name of Major Smith.
The terms were asked by Capt.
Law, and the reply was, he would allow one ship to remove his people in, and the balance of his public property would be ours.
He demanded three 1 ours' time, for the purpose of seeing Commodore Renshaw, who was on the Westfield, some miles distant.--Capt.
Law proposed to go in his vessel, but Capt. Lubbock insisted he should go in a gig, and anchor his vessel exactly where she was until the truce was over.
Law thought it hard, but agreed.
The senior officer of the Harriet Lane was allowed to accompany Capt.
Law, on his parole of honor to return.

Capt. Lubbock then pushed off, and then went ashore to report to Gen. Magruder.
Having made his report, the General returned with him to the wharf where the Harriet Lane and the Bayou City were lying.
The three hours now were drawing to a close, and Gen. Magruder ordered Col. Green to accompany Capt. Lubbock to close the negotiations.
On approaching the Clifton they found her under way. The excuse given by Capt.
Law was that he was acting under orders from Commodore Renshaw.
Just before they went aboard, they saw the Westfield blow up, she having been fired by the enemy.
Capt. Lubbock charged Law with a breach of faith, and told him he considered his running away, under the circumstances, equivalent to stealing so much Confederate property. --Capt.
Law could bring nothing to bear against the blunt talk of Capt. Lubbock. Capt. Lubbock and Col. Green then left the vessel and made report to Gen. Magruder, and in the meantime all the vessels left, carrying white flags.
Unfortunately the Bayou City had got so entangled in the wheel of the Harriet Lane that she could not be extricated in time for pursuit.
Company B (Capt. Well's company) and others of our men fired one round of grape, and then a solid shot, from one of the big guns, at the Owasso, through the stern of the Lane, the shot making a port hole for themselves through her bulwarks.
The Owasso steamed away after her cowardly fellows and our land batteries fired round after round at her till she turned Fort Point.

Major Smith then jumped on board the John F. Carr, and called out for volunteers to follow the Owasso and avenge Capt. Weir.
He soon obtained all he wanted, and pursued the propeller; but she was too swift, and too far ahead on her way out of the harbor, and he was obliged to content himself with capturing the Yankee bark in the stream, laden with potatoes, etc., and the coat vessel at Pelican Spit.
Those which escaped were three steamers and two sail vessels.

Capt. Wm. M. Armstrong went on board the Lane after the battle, and found lying in the blood on deck a bible.
He picked it up and remarked, "Now I am going to open this bible this new year's day, and the first passage I read I will take as an omen for the new year." He opened it carelessly, and the first passage his eye fell on was the inverse of the 20th chapter of Deuteronomy. "When though out to battle against thine enemies, and asset horses and chariots, and a people more than thou, be not afraid of them: for the Lord thy God is with thee, which brought thee up out of the land of Egypt!" It is a good omen, as well as a most startling circumstance.

The list of casualties, so far reported, on our side, is about 12 killed and mortally wounded, and 70 wounded, not mortally.
The enemy's loss is great, but not ascertained.
Every officer on the Harriet Lane wounded, down to the master.
Maj. Smith won the spolia spina, killing Capt. Wainwright with his own hand.
The crew of the Harriet Lane was made up of the old crews of the Congress and Cumberland.
One of the officers remarked that it was a hard case to be Merrimacked a second time.
This crew, however, as they were marched off the vessel, remarked, this is New Year's our liberty day.

div3.head: Not an iron clad.
div3.p:
--The Federal gunboat Hatteras, recently sunk by a Confederate steamer, supposed to be the Florida, was not an iron clad, as reported by the telegrams sent to the press.--She was a side wheel steamer of 1,100 tons, carrying three or four rifled guns.
She was built of iron, but not armored with it. In talking and writing people are apt to confound iron built vessels with iron clads.

div3.head: Progress of the war.
div3.p: From United States papers, of the 231 inst., we make up a summary of the more interesting news contained in them:

div4.head: The discontent is the Yankee army — a Company Threatened to be shot down — the Accurate information of the rebels.
div4.p:
A correspondent of the New York Tribunes writing from the left grand division of Burnside's army on the 20th, says that two days before that throughout the entire army there were the most unmistakable signs of an immediate intention to advance against the enemy.
The advance had in fact commenced, and the pontoon train had started for its destination.
He adds:

q.p:
The preliminary orders had all been issued; the surgeons had been thronged by the timorous, suddenly seized with nameless and indescribable diseases, while others were animated with the excitement of an impending battle.
Since then the movement has been twice postponed for 24 hours, and there is now a suspicious that it may be still further delayed — perhaps indefinitely.
Our own opinion is that the excessively cold weather, which suddenly set in just as the movement was to commence, has occasioned the delay.
A slight wound on such days as we have seen would seriously endanger life, and mercy to the army demanded that a battle should not be offered at such a time.
It may be that the enemy, who have exhibited too much knowledge of what was in progress, have shown by counter movements that our plans would probably have proved unsuccessful.
There is probably no point available for a crossing at which the enemy have not constructed rifle pits, or loop-holed block houses.
Several officers, who were yesterday reconnoitering the course of the rivers, fancied they had discovered a quiet spot, suitable for the bridges, which had escaped the vigilance of the enemy.
Leaving their horses in the woods, they dropped down to the bottom lands through which the river courses, and, scrutinizing the secluded locality, were unable to discover any signs of rifle pits or rebels.
Presently, however, several gray backs were seen moving from behind a grass grown embankment, which proved to have been converted into a defence against the crossing of the river.
We may look for a warm reception from the sharpshooters whenever and wherever the operations of the bridge-builders are commenced.

div4.p:
There has been much given to the public of late calculated and diminish the good opinion in which the Army of the Potomac had previously been held.
Those who have been recently exaggerating the discontent and discouragement of the soldiers, will seize with avidity upon the fact of the recent mutiny of a German battery, to confirm their high-colored reports.
Such stories do great injustice to the army and injury to the service.
Nothing like what they have represented in reality exists.
It is true that a prolonged period of inactivity, during which the men have been unpaid, and unable to purchase anything for themselves or send money to their families, has occasioned many murmurings and complaints; yet nothing like disloyalty or insubordination can with any truth be said to pervade the army.

When we lately returned to the army having been several weeks absent, there had apparently arisen a change in the morale of the men, whom we had believed, immediately after the battle of Fredericksburg, to have been in excellent spirits.
A more extended observation has produced the conviction that the discontent, where it does exist, is not of a kind to give serious cause for apprehension, and that the existence of this demoralization is by no means general.
Perhaps a visit from the Paymaster — perhaps a good days match — would clear the atmosphere from the slightest signs of discontent.

The recent mutiny, of which there are many various versions and accounts already circulating in camp, was simply and wholly this: Company C, of the New York Artillery Battalion, informed their Sergeant that they would not turn out to fight until they were paid.
The Sergeant told the Lieutenant, the Lieutenant told the Adjutant General, who in turn told Gen. Hayes.
The General immediately ordered that unless they should consent to turn out the company should be shot down.
This morning, accordingly, Captain Graham had ready a section of his battery, and it was arranged that the Adjutant General should address them in German preparatory to executing the threat.
The company hearing of it quietly communicated to their Sergeant and he to his Lieutenant, and he again to the Adjutant General, and finally to General Hayes, that they would obey orders without any hesitation.
The status quo was accordingly restored, and Battery C, New York Battalion, is as loyal as ever, the Paymaster having since arrived and supplied them with their full arrears in green-backs.

div4.head: Why the army of the Potomac should fall back.
div4.p: Under the above caption, we find the following in the New York Post:

q.p:
While our army on the Rappahannock lies Idle, or prepares to move in a direction which actually increases its distance in time from the army in Tennessee, and thus, at every mile of progress, makes it less and less easy to send reinforcements from the East to Rosecrane, the public is naturally uneasy at the reports which come from the West of reinforcements going down to the rebels from Virginia.
It is probably true that Lee is sending troops to Tennessee.
Why should he not?
The risk is small, and the object he may hope to gain is important.
With twenty thousand good men he can dispute the advance of our army from the Rappahannock; such a General as Jackson — tenacious, daring, and determined — could increase the natural difficulties of the country between Fredericksburg and Richmond so greatly that at every water-course we should be delayed; and the rebel army of Tennessee, strengthened by the bulk of Lee's army, would have abundant time to fall upon Rosecrane and Grant and destroy them before our Eastern forces could reach the rebel capital.

div4.p:
And even if, in such a case, we got to Richmond, what then?
Would that make up to us the loss of Tennessee--the defeat of our armies there?
Surely not.

We hold, then, that the rumored determination of Gen. Halleck to send a large part of the Potomac army to the West; is a sign that he wisely appreciates our dangers, and means to meet the enemy where he can have him at the greatest advantage.
With 50,000 men left to defend Washington and guard the line of the Potomac, and no further attempts at offensive movements in Virginia, we would quickly concentrate such a force under Rosecrane and other Generals in the West as would office to open the Mississippi, and to march an army into the cotton States.
Then Richmond would fall of itself.

div4.head: The Contagion of Secession.
div4.p: The New York Tribune, of Friday last, has quite a lengthy editorial, under the caption "The"Contagion of Secession." It shows that the North is no longer a unit on the "crushing out" question, and that the physic is working too well for old white-coated Greeley to stop it. The Tribune says:

q.p:
We are beginning to feel the effects of woful example.
The diabolical spirit of rebellion not only encounters us in the field, but it has entered our legislative chambers, and, under the malign promptings of the Democratic party, bent upon rule or ruin, it is tampering with the popular loyalty.--One year ago men only murmured treason; but success has opened their mouths and filled their hearts with abominable political devices.
We are beginning to see that about the worst battle lost to the Union cause thus far is that of the New York State election.
Nobody believes Horatio Seymour to be friendly to the Administration, or to feel any honest sympathy with its embarrassments — yet he is elected Governor.
The tools in Albany has given us a bitter foretaste of possible anarchy.
From the West we hear of schemes designed by the desperate and disaffected — conspiracies tending to fresh ruptured and the final overthrow of the Republic.
Wicked man, even at the North, are beginning openly and shamelessly to daily with disunion, and propose, since dislocation has come into fashion to multiply the fragments of our institutions.
All this is terrible.
We can better afford to lose fifty fights than thus to weaken the morality of our cause.
We can better afford to submit to invasion than thus to make disintegration familiar to our constituencies.
We can better afford to let the slaveholding soldier bivouac in the Capitol than to be betrayed into negotiations which are full of danger, or to daily with compromise which, with their adoption, must precipitate us into unmitigated anarchy.
Already we begin to hear of Western Confederacies, of New England Confederacies, of Middle States transmogrified into Middle Confederacies.
Already we have hints of new and tempting combinations, aiming at safe and convenient boundaries and the monopoly of internal navigation.
Already the coming Congress cast their shadow before; and, busy as the Devil always has been in Washington, a time is coming when he will redouble his activity in that uneasy seat of an endangered Government.
Hitherto the restoration of the Union has been with the mass of the people, a matter of sentiment; but a time is at hand which will not be in the least poetical, and when we must confront public danger hardened into the most vulgar concrete.

div4.p:
Gentlemen who desire to be elected to Congress, not as patriots, but simply and nakedly as anti-Republicans, or anti-Government men, cannot be supposed to care much for the perpetuity of our institutions.
They expect to fatten upon our national troubles.
They are ghouls who will care little how cold the corpse may be, if, sooner or latter, they may fairly get their teeth into it. They live, plot, plan spout, intrigue, bargain, and scheme, solely for personal engagement.
Their loyalty is limited by their own lives, and no thought of the weal or woe of posterity enters into their calculations.
If, with the recognition of the Confederacy, these moral traitors could be banished, and, with them, their whole brand of canal voters — if we could send them to rest in the black bosoms of their Confederate friends — if the honor, worth, religion, intelligence, and wealth of the North could have but a fair chance of exercising their legitimate influence — we might consider with greater coolness the success of the Southern treason.
But there men, after the accomplished dismemberment, would remain — would still be with us though not of us — would be then, as they are now, and as they always have been, the ready agents of slavery, and the paid pimps of the slaveholding interest.
Establish a State upon the basis of man owning upon this continent, and the minds of Wood, Brooks, Seymour, and all that genus will gravitate towards it with all the force of a bad nature.
Once these men in power and the Northern Republic would be brought, if not the born thrall of the Davis dynasty, ready in Cabinet and Congress to do its dirty and demoniac work; ready to catch its runaways; ready to walk at the revival of the African slave trade; ready to join an alliance against the moral sense of mankind; ready to promote the secession of the West from the East; ready for war upon New England; ready to make our poor shadow of a Government in Washington as much the tool of the Southern Confederacy as ever the Cabinet of Charles H. was the tool of the French monarch.
Political chafferers, in the sacred name of Democracy, would sell themselves first, and next their neighbors.
There could be for us no permanence, no prosperity, no private happiness, and no public greatness.

It may be said that we exaggerate this danger.
We do not think so. For the political power of the Confederacy would be in the hands of a few men, who have been educated to detest the Union, and who would be ill satisfied with that partial success which left even a respectable fragment of the old Republic yet entire.
Once fairly separated, they would begin to feel wants, the existence of which they do not now admit, and they would be only too ready to avail themselves of those commercial abilities which they have heretofore affected to despise.
The great serpent of slavery would reverse its trail, and look with longing eyes towards a North left at its mercy by the dissensions and disaffection of its own children.
Our social freedom would be a perpetual aggravation of the bad temper and jealousy which are the inseparable adjuncts of slaveholding.
If we were prosperous, our prosperity would be a continual rebuke of that sin which has been called "the sum of all villainies;" and if we were hopelessly weakened by the dismemberment, our cities and our farms would be the cheap prey of every mad partisan who chose to promote a raid.
Nor should we be without a hatred of slavery, intensified by the woes of which it had been the fruitful mother, and any effort to check or to silence the expression of that sentiment would but complicate the public dilemma.
We should still have pro- slavery Governors, pro-slavery Senators, pro slavery Presidents, and pro-slavery Representatives; and the very existence of a determined and uncompromising opposition would drive them into disgraceful diplomacies and intrigues, not to be thought of without horror!
If we speak sharply, we beg the reader to believe that we speak sincerely.
We have not, nor will we pretend to have, any confidence in the public virtue of that hungry place-hunter who prates of the wrongs of the South and of the sins of the North--who has fine words for the Richmond regime, and foul words for his own constitutional rulers — who would restore the Union by muzzling discussion, and by a declaration of the sanctity of involuntary servitude with all the solemnities of an act of public faith — who feels it to be a duty to apologize for his own loyalty and for the treason of the public enemy — who is half this and half that, and not wholly, body, soul, and spirit, the honest and unquestioning devotee of the Constitution and the laws — who wastes that indignation upon the foes of slavery which he should naturally bestow upon his friends — who is as utterly without pity for the poor and defenceless as he is ignorant of that simple law of labor which makes the prosperity of the employer dependent upon his justice — who is, in short, a creature of sham and of subterfuge and participates in public affairs without one ennobling sentiment or one benevolent aspiration.
Why should this poor hybrid, half monarchist and half democrat, pretend to any reverence for human rights, or be at all coy about selling others, since he is so ready to sell himself?
Let us see to it that the triumph of the Secessionists does not open for him a market.

div4.head: Address of a Newly-elected U. S. Senator.
div4.p:
Col. Wall, the recently elected U. S. Senator from New Jersey, was serenaded in Philadelphia on the 21st inst. He was introduced by Mr. James C. Vandyke in a brief speech, in which a eulogy was paid to the words "traitor," "rebel"--words which he said had more than ordinary significance because Washington and his compatriots were proud to be honored with such appellations.
We extract the following from his speech, as reported in the Press:

I know, fellow-citizens, that there are many of us here to-night who, like honest Gonsalvo in Shakespeare's play of the Tempest, would give a "furlong of sea for a barren acre of ground." My friends, we must stick to the ship, and, whatever be its fate, you and I must share its destiny.
There is a precious freight on board this tempest tossed bark.
The waters are white with the foam beneath her bow. There is no time to take to the long boat.
That tempest-tossed vessel is freighted also with the precious Constitution our fathers gave us. The compass by which they steered it is still on board that vessel, and in order to preserve it we have got to stick to the ship.
[Cries of "that's so," and cheers] My friends, there are men now navigating that vessel who are attempting to steer her by the compass of coercion, and to drive her by the chart of a "higher law." [Cheers and counter cheers] It is to watch these men that we have got to stick to the ship.
I do not believe that the old vessel will ever be saved until a Democratic commander again walks the deck [cheers] and the strong hand of a Democratic pilot is upon her helm.
[Renewed applause and cheers for Wall]

Fellow-citizens, I have recently at the hands of the Legislature of the State of New Jersey, [three cheers] been tendered the responsible office of Senator of the United States.
I go there, my friends, as I understand it, to advocate as far as my limited abilities will permit — to advocate, I say, peace in that body.
[Cheers for "peace."] I cannot say, my friends, how this is to be brought about, but I believe I speak the sentiments of the people of New Jersey, and not only of the people of New Jersey, but of the loyal people of Pennsylvania, when I say that they will hail the hour, that shall bring us from out this lurid tempest of war into the calm and blessed shade of a long and lasting peace.
[Cheers] My friends, I go, also, as I understand it, upon the floor of the Senate of the U. States to advocate those great principles of civil liberty which were handed down to us from our fathers [renewed cheers,] those great principles which are embodied in the amendments to the Constitution of the United States, every one of which I am sorry to say, has been trampled under foot by the present Administration.
[Applause]

Gentlemen, you will recollect that it is but a few months ago that men were afraid to express the truth that was in them; but now, how great the charge!
A short time ago, I gentlemen, endured obioquy and insult of the grossest character.
Aye, my family had to submit to the grossest insults in the city of Burlington, and my daughters insulted by the wenches on the streets.
When I ventured to complain I was charged with disloyalty.
I have had no distinct accusation against me, though I have time after time demanded to know it. I wrote to Mr. Cameron to know why I had been imprisoned in the dungeons of Fort Lafayette.
[Cheers and groans for Cameron.] But, gentlemen, after I had been imprisoned for weeks, and then let free, I wrote to Mr. William H. Seward.
I said: "Sir, I have written to the Secretary of War for the purpose of being informed why I was put in the bastiles of the Administration; now please tell me why I was let out?
[Cheers and laugher.] I have not been able to find out either.

Charles W. Carrigan followed in a short speech and the crowd soon after dispersed.
The band played numerous tunes, but not one was of a national character.
The Cincinnati Enquirer thus commends the action of its political allies in New Jersey:

Col. Wall was one of the first victims thrown into the Administration bastile in New York by Simon Cameron.
He is an able, bold, and eloquent man, and has been opposed to the war from the start.
He is just the man for Senator.
The Administration throws him into a bastile — the people make him Senator.

div4.head: The capture of Transports and a gunboat on the Cumberland River.
div4.p:
The Evansville (Ind.) Journal has an account of Wheeler's horse marine raid on the Cumberland river.
The first boat captured was the transport Hastings with wounded on board.
The Journal says:

q.p:
Among the passengers on the Hastings was Mr. Gaddle, the correspondent of the Cincinnati Commercial, who found an old acquaintance in the person of Adjutant Buford, of Wheeler's brigade, the rebels engaged in this barbarous outrage being under the immediate command of Colonel Wade.--After much pleading with the Adjutant, and representing the cruelty to and certain destruction of the wounded, Mr. Gaddle prevailed on the rebels to agree that the Hastings should be let off with the wounded, on condition that she shall never again be used in the service of the Government, and that the cotton on board should be pitched into the river when she arrived at Louisville.
By this time the Parthenia hove in sight, and in turn was rounded to, made land, and was thoroughly gutted.
The rebels being many of them drunk, acted like demons, shouting and reveling like Bacchanalians, destroying goods and furniture, robbing the sick and wounded of their money, clothing, blankets, &c.

div4.p:
While this scene was being enacted, and before either of the boats had been set on fire, the gunboat Siddall hove in sight.
No sooner had she made her appearance then the rebels took to their heels in the wildest confusion and alarm, a few artillery men only remaining at their guns, the others taking refuge behind the hills.
The Siddall came on down, the men capture on the boats expecting every moment to see her open with her guns on the terrified rebels.
But they were deemed to shameful and bitter disappointment.
As the Siddall came nearly opposite the rebel battery it opened on her, firing three shots, when Lieut-Van-Dorn struck his flag and surrendered without firing a shot, the man who obeyed the pusillanimous and cowardly order of her traitorous commander being wounded in the leg while lowering the flag.

The gunboat was dismounted, her guns and ammunition being thrown overboard, and then she, with the Trip and Parthenia, were set fire to and burned.
Lieut. Steele fully confirms the report of the shooting of the negroes on the boats in cold blood.
There is no doubt in the minds of any with whom we have conversed, who witnessed the affair, that the rebels could have been driven away and the boats all saved had the officer commanding the gunboat possessed a loyal and courageous spirit.
It is some consolation to know that he is in the hands of the rebels, and may chance to be hung by them.
If his conduct was as is represented — and we have every reason to believe it true — it will certainly be the duty of our Government to hang or shoot him when exchanged, If he should ever be exchanged.

div4.head: Can't depend on the Illinois troops.
div4.p:
We have already announced the fact that the 109th regiment of Illinois volunteers has in good part deserted to the Confederates.
The Cincinnati Commercial says of it:

q.p:
The 109th Illinois regiment mutinied, a few days ago, at Holly Springs.
This regiment was raised at Anna, a place in that portion of Illinois known as Egypt, where the Democracy cast an almost unanimous vote.
The Lieutenant-Colonel went over to the enemy; the other officers and men, except the Colonel, who is a loyal man, are under arrest.
This regiment, before it left Illinois, drove a farmer out of his house at midnight because he had hired two negroes.
There are said to be one or two other Southern Illinois regiments who are not to be depended upon.

div4.p: The Louisville Journal has a letter from Columbus, Ky., of the 11th inst., which says:

q.p:
Among the officers taken [at the surprise and rout of the rebels at Kuob Creek] was one P. H. Strickland, Second Lieutenant in company A, 1st Tennessee Partisan Rangers.
Upon Lieut. Strickland Capt. Moore found forty paroles of men belonging to the 109th Illinois. Major Strickland, of the 52d Indiana, being a relative of Lieut. Strickland, they at once entered into free and confidential conversation.
Among other things, the Lieutenant informed the Major that every man in the 109th Illinois, from the Colonel down, belonged to the Knights of the Golden Circle, and that they (the rebels) were afraid we would find it out, because they were so bold and impudent about it — He also said that there were very many officers in our army belonging to that society, and that they rendered the Confederates more service than they did the Federals.
Continuing, he added that we had no idea of the strength of that society in the North, and that through it they were apprised of all important army matters.

div4.head: The condition of the Yankee army.
div4.p: A New York letter, of the 22d, says:

q.p:
In four months the time of service of some thirty-eight regiments from this State will be up and the question as to their disposition is now under consideration by the military authorities--Governor Seymour is understood to be in favor of their return home and subsequent re-enlistment.
Some of these regiments, however, do not number, rank and file, over one hundred men each, and the question in what manner these shattered remains of regiments are to be recruited up to their full numbers will probably prove a difficult one to answer.
The Adjutant General, however, will, it is expected, soon issue an order in regard to the matter.

div4.head: Lincoln again in doubt.
div4.p: A newspaper correspondent fells the following:

Some one sent President Lincoln a batch of newspaper criticisms upon him and his conduct of the war last week.
In speaking about it to a friend, Mr. Lincoln said:

q.p: "Having an hour to spare, on Sunday, I read this batch of editorials, and when I was through reading I asked myself, Abraham Lincoln, are you a man or a dog?"

div4.p: The writer does not state what conclusion Mr. Lincoln arrived at, but leaves us to suppose he regards it as an open question.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p: Grant Thorburn ("Laurie Todd,") died at New Haven, Conn., on the 22d inst., in the 20th year of his age.
The bark Achilles left New York last week with 5,000 barrels of flour for the sufferers in England.
The study of the Spanish language has been discontinued at West Point.
The National Intelligencer published the "intercepted dispatches" at the regular advertising rates.

The Mormon Saints have established a theatre at Salt Lake City, Brigham Young and President Kimball officiating at the opening Songs, dances, the comedy of "The Honeymoon;" and the farce of "Paddy Miles's Boy," made up the initiatory bill.
Cephas Brainerd, of Philadelphia, has been appointed arbitrator on the part of the United States, under the treaty with Great Britain, for the more effectual suppression of the slave trade.

div3.head: Confederate States Congress.
div3.p: Tuesday, January 27, 1863.
Senate.--The Senate met at 12 o'clock.

Mr. Sparrow, of Louisiana, offered a resolution asking the Secretary of the Treasury for information as to how much cotton has been purchased by the Government, the names of the purchasing agents.
etc.
Mr. Phelar, of Miss., Introduced a bill (which was referred) fixing the price of cotton which had been destroyed by the Government at fifteen cents.
The bill providing for a Supreme Court of the Confederate States, with one Chief and four Associate Justices--the Chief with a salary of $7,000, and the Associates $6,000 each, was taken up.
After much debate, in which the pecuniary question was slightly dwelt upon, and all other questions freely enlarged upon, the salary of the Chief was fixed at $5,500 and his Associates at $5,000.
Mr. Clay, of Ala., offered the following, to go in as a 6th section:

That sections 45 and 45 an act of the Provisional Congress, entitled an act to establish Judicial Courts of the Confederate States of America, approved 16th March, 1861. be and the same are hereby repealed.

Mr. Clay said the sections he proposed to repeal almost entirely limited the jurisdiction of the State Courts within the power of the Courts of the Confederate States, and there was no feature of the Constitution, if construed by this section, which could not be made to favor the consolidation of the Government.
He did not, however, intend to go into an argument on the question.
A debate ensued, during which the Senate adjourned.
House of Representatives.--House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

Mr. Jones, the Delegate from the Choctaw Territory, offered a resolution that there be printed, for distribution to the different Indian tribes within the bounds of the Confederate States, two hundred additional copies of the report of the Commissioner of Indian Affairs.
Agreed to.

The Chair stated that the unfinished business before the House was the resolution of the gentleman from Kentucky, (Mr. Crockett,) to declare the basis upon which alone peace propositions shall be offered or entertained by this Government.

Mr. Moore, of Kentucky, who was entitled to the floor, said he was utterly and entirely opposed to the passage of the resolution.
It was not necessary to inform the people of the North what was the policy of this Government upon the subject of peace.
This might be understood from the messages of the President, and seen in the action of both branches of Congress.
He proceeded to allude to the position of his own State. (Kentucky,) and declared that there had not been a day nor an hour since the commencement of the war when she would not, if opportunity had been afforded, ranged herself with her sister States of the South.
Mr. Crockett explained the motives which actuated him in offering the resolutions; but said there were matters connected with its consideration which he was unwilling to discuss in open session.
Mr. Breckenridge, of Ky., called the question upon the motion to refer the resolutions; which was agreed to, and they were referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Mr. Vest of Mo., presented a bill in relation to the transfer of troops.
Referred to the Military Committee.

Mr. McLean, of N. C., offered a resolution to request the President to communicate to this House, if not incompatible with the public interest, in what States of the Confederacy the Conscript law has been or is now being enforced, and whether any State or States of the Confederacy have been exempted from its operation; and also, whether any State or States of the Confederacy have in its or their service any number of troops, as served State forces, which have been raised out of persons at the time subject to the Conscript acts.--Agreed to.
Mr. Smith, of N. C., offered the following resolution, which was agreed to:

Resolved, That the Committee on the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments and Military Transportation be directed to inquire into the expediency of providing for the exemption of such contracts as have been or may be hereafter made with State authorities for the supply of clothing to the troops from such States from the late act abolishing commutation therefor, approved October 8, 1862, and to report by bill or otherwise.--Agreed to.

Mr. Smith also introduced a bill, to be entitled an act to amend an act entitled an act to organize the Department of State, approved February 21st, 1861. This bill provides for the repeal of the 4th section of the former act. Referred to the Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., introduced a bill to provide for the arrest of soldiers absent from their commands without leave, and providing compensation for their captors.
Ordered to be printed and referred to the Military Committee.
Also, a bill to amend an act relative to prisoners of war. Referred.

Also, a bill to allow minors to hold commissions in the armies of the Confederate States.
Referred to the Military Committee.
Also, a bill to provide for the appointment of additional Quartermasters in the Provisional Army Referred to the Military Committee.

Also, a bill to increase the strength and confidency of heavy artillery for coast defences and other purposes.
Referred.

Also, a bill to provide for the safe and expeditions transportation of troops and munitions of war by railroad.
Referred to the Committee on Military Transportation.

Also, a resolution that the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments be instructed to inquire into the expediency of increasing the compensation for horses killed in battle and of providing for compensation for horses lest or disabled in service, where no fault attaches to the owners thereof, and to report by bill or otherwise.
Agreed to

Also, a resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to inquire into the expediency of diminishing the number of Partism Ranger Corps new in service, and improving the efficiency of their organization, and to report by bill or otherwise.
Agreed to

Mr. McQueen, of S. C., presented a bill to amend an act entitled an act to establish the General Staff of the Army of the Confederate States.
Referred to Military Committee.

Mr. Farrow, of S. C., introduced a bill relative to orders from Heads of Departments.
Referred to Military Committee.

Mr. Heickell, of Tenn., a resolution that the privilege accorded by this House to certain committees of this House to report at any time be withdrawn.
Laid on the table.

Mr. Foote, of Tenn., offered a resolution that the Committee on the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments be introduced to inquire whether or not great abuses have occurred in the transportation service, whereby persons concerned in speculative operations have been allowed, by the connivance of persons in the employment of the Government, to transport commodities on their own account, to the exclusion of others, and even of the Government itself, by which great public mischief has occurred.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the same committee be instructed to inquire into the amount of losses in Commissary and Quartermaster's supplies at Nashville, Clarksville.
Bowling Green, and Manassas, upon the evacuation of those places by our armies, with such particulars as may enable Congress to understand whether those losses were necessarily incurred, or were the neglect of officials, or mismanagement.
Agreed to.

Also, a resolution that the same committee be instructed to inquire into the facts and circumstances connected with the large accumulation of Commissary supplies at Manassas, and in that vicinage, just before the evacuation of that post by our army, and that said committee particularly inquire whether such accumulation of supplies at that place, at the period specified, was in accordance with the advice of Gen. Johnston, or in opposition thereto; and, also, that said committee do inquire, also, whether the flour accumulated in the vicinage mentioned was flour ground in the country immediately proximate to the position of our army, or flour ground in the neighborhood of Richmond, at higher prices than flour was then commanding in the neighborhood of the army, and transported at great additional expanse to the place where it was needed.
Agreed to.
Mr. Foote also offered the following joint resolution which, after some discussion, was referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Resolved. That the Congress of the Confederate States of America does cordially concur in the kind and complimentary language of the President in his late message in regard to "the enlightened ruler of the French nation," that it is evidently time as the President has so emphatically declared that "the clear and direct imitation contained in the language of the French note, that our ability to maid in our independence has been fully established, was not controverted by the answer of either of the Cabinets to which it was addressed," and that "it is indeed difficult to conceive a just ground for longer delay on the subject, after reading the statement of facts contained in the latter emanating from the minister of his Imperial Majesty."
Mr. Lyons, of Virginia, offered a joint resolution as a substitute for the above, which was referred, with the resolution of Mr. Foote, to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Mr. Foote also offered a joint resolution on the question of retaliation and a resolution in respect to certain tobacco, supposed to be the property of August Belmont, of N. Y. The first was laid upon the table, and the other referred to Judiciary Committee.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, the House went into secret session.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p: Senate--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by Lieut. Gov. Montague.
The Senate was notified that the House had passed the bill incorporating the Confederate Express Company, and bill exempting from military duty all persons who have furnished substitutes for the war.

Bills were reported for increasing the hospital accommodation of the Lexington Virginia Military Institute to the extent of $3,000, and appropriating $7.44 to pay Gen. Alfred Beckley for military services performed by him; so much of the report of the Board of Visitors to the Va. Military Institute as refers to an increase in the annuity of the said institution was referred to the Committee on Finance and Claims.

The Finance Committee reported that it was inexpedient to grant the petition of E. S. Arnold, late Sheriff of Kanawha, asking to be refunded certain taxes paid by him into the treasury.
Report received.

The bill for establishing an agency at Richmond for receiving and forwarding clothing, shoes and other supplies to Virginia soldiers, was amended so as to make the agent responsible for the supplies received.
The bill allowing but one Major to each regiment was ordered to be engrossed; also, the bill to sell the State's Interest in the Lidsboro' and Cincinnati Railroad.

A resolution was adopted suspending the operation of the law of Oct. 31, 1862, so far as relates to the county of Carolina.
Reported to House for concurrence.
A bill was introduced, on motion of Mr. Garnett, for incorporating the Richmond and New Bridge Turnpike Company in Henrico county.
By resolution of Mr. Brannon, the Committee on Finance were authorized to inquire into the expediency of prohibiting licenses to auctioneers for the sale of staple products, goods and manufacturers.

The Committee on General Laws, by resolution of Mr. Dickenson, of Prince Edward, was authorized to inquire into the expediency of amending the charter of the Trustees of the Union Theological Seminary.

Joint resolutions respecting arrest of civilians by military authorities, introduced by Mr. Collier, were referred to the Committee on Confederate Nations.
A series of resolutions relative to "property in slaves" offered last session by Mr. Collier, were referred to the Committee on Courts of Justice.
Mr. Marshall, of Fauquier, offered a series of resolutions relative to the country's credit and the currency, and the proper means of preserving both; which were read and appropriately referred.

Mr. Brannon offered a resolution of inquiry into the expediency of reporting a bill to authorize the issue of Treasury notes of an amount sufficient to meet the outstanding notes of the State, and temporary loans fundable is the registered stock of the Commonwealth in sums of one hundred dollars and multiples of one hundred dollars; which was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Nash, of Chesterfield, the Senate adjourned.

House of Delegates.--The House met at 12 o'clock M., Mr. McCamant in the chair.
Prayer by the Rev. Mr. Burrows.
The bill for dispensing with the fence laws in certain counties which have been overrun by the public enemy, and legalizing the acts of County Courts in relation thereto, was taken up and passed.
The bill imposing a fine upon Justices of the Peace for falling to attend Court when summoned so to do, passed.
The bill incorporating the Manchester and Petersburg Turnpike Company, also passed.

A message was received from the Senate, with a resolution passed by that body, in which they ask the concurrence of this House, authorizing the Governor to suspend from the operations of the law passed the 31 of October, 1862, relative to public defences, such counties whose loss of slaves, because of the presence of the public enemy, has affected their agricultural interests.
Mr. Hunter moved to take up and consider the resolution, which was carried, and the resolution agreed to.
The bill for issuing Treasury notes of a less denomination than one dollar was, on motion of Mr. Robertson, laid on the table.
A message was received from the Governor in response to a resolution passed by the House on yesterday, relative to the number of militia called out by him in the spring of 1862, their pay, etc.

Senate bill allowing Sarah V. Thornton to remove certain slaves from this Commonwealth to North Carolina, was passed; Senate bill amending the Code of Virginia so as to extend the time of filling complaints in cases of contested elections — passed.
The following bill was taken up and passed:

list.item: 1. be it enacted by the General Assembly, that no person who has heretofore furnished, according to law, a substitute in the Confederate military service under the proclamation of the Governor, of the 10th day of January, 1863, except in cases where such substitute has been or is liable to be called upon, under an existing law of the Confederate States, to perform his own tour of duty, but every such person shall be entitled to his discharge.

2. the Governor is empowered and directed to determine all questions of exemptions arising under the said proclamation, or any future proclamation, claimed by any person by reason of his having furnished a substitute.
3. this act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.p: resolutions of Inquiry.--the following resolutions of Inquiry were submitted by Mr. Gilmer, into the expediency of appointing one or more agents for the purchase of into the expediency of appointing an Inspector of flour in the town of Danville; into the expediency of enrolling all the free negroes in the Commonwealth, male and female, and employing them as teamsterr, nurses, cooks, &c.
Mr. Hunter submitted the following which was agreed to:
Resolved, that the Committee on Confederate Relations take into consideration, and report their opinion upon, the subject matter of the following inquiries, to wit:

list.item:
1.
Would it be right and proper, in respect to our general political system, or upon the reason of expediency, or upon any other ground, for the Commonwealth of Virginia to take charge of, for the purpose of prosecution, under the State laws, any person, either officer or private, confined during the present war by the Confederate Government.

2.
Is it within the competency of the government of Virginia, in the absence of specific legislation on the subject, to receive such persons, and take the necessary means to have them prosecuted under the State laws.
3. Can the civil magistrates of the Commonwealth so receive and deal with such persons, and would it be expedient for them so to do?
4. Is it within the constitutional competency of the Governor of this Commonwealth to enter into any cartel for the exchange of prisoners with the Government of the United States?

div3.p: The bill "to provide hospital accommodations for the sick and wounded soldiers of this State, and depots for clothing for troops in the field," was called up. The bill was advocated by Messrs. Anderson, of Botetourt, and Beauford; but the latter, for reasons explained moved to make it the special order of the day for Friday next.
Mr. Hunter was in favor of the oldest of the bill, but thought it needed home amendments; he therefore favored its postponement until Friday, which was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Fleming, the House, at 1½ o'clock, adjourned until to-morrow.
Supreme Court of Appeals.--The following decisions were announced yesterday by the Judges of the above Court:

The Petersburg Fire and Marine Company vs. Hardy.
Argued by Wm. T. Joynes for the plaintiff and James Alfred Jones and Thomas H. Gholson for the defendants.
Judgment of the Circuit Court of the city of Petersburg affirmed.

The Virginia Central Railroad Company vs. Wickham.
Argued by James Lyons and P. R. Grattan for the plaintiff, and John B. Young for the defendant.
Judgment of the Circuit Court of Hanover county affirmed.

Wilkinson vs. Hall.
Argued by Cyruda Branch and Arthur A. Morson for the appellant, and Lemuel J. Bowden for the appelies.
Decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Williamsburg and county of James City reversed and injunction reinstated and perpetuated.

div3.head: Serious Accident
div3.p:
--Falling of a Bridge and Drowning of several Paroled Abolition Prisoners.--Yesterday morning shortly after 3 o'clock, 797 of the paroled Abolition prisoners, recently captured at Murfreesboro', Tenn, started from the Libby prison, corner of 20th and Cary streets, in charge of Lieut. Bossieux, en route for the Petersburg Depot, where the men were to take the cars for City Point.
The rear cars had been backed down 8th street till within a few feet of the southern side of the James River and Kanawha Canal, the engine being near the gate of the bridge spanning James river.
The head of the column had reached the car next to the engine, and the men were being put aboard, when suddenly an awful crash was heard, succeeded by screams and dries for help.
It was found that the iron bridge crossing the canal where it intersects 8th street had yielded to the weight of some 75 or 100 Abolition soldiers who had crowded on it, and breaking in two parts had with its living load, been precipitated a distance of twenty-five feet in the surging waters of the canal below it. The struggling men were rescued with all the haste that could be used, considering the darkness that at the time enveloped everything.
Some who were adopts in swimming struck out boldly into the basin, and were only recalled after considerable exertion; but the majority seized on everything that presented a chance for escape from the danger that menaced them.
As soon as the men could be gathered together they were put on board the cars and the train proceeded in the direction of Petersburg.
During the day, in the city, after the catastrophe became known, the wildest rumors got afloat.
The number of Abolition soldiers drowned was at first stated at not less than fifty but towards night the number was reduced one-half.
Included in the number said to have met a watery grave, were three of the guards, but if any did fall in they were rescued, as none were missing.
It is probable that by this catastrophe five or six persons lost their lives.
On calling the roll of Yankees, at City Point, five were found missing.
A bay, who was selling bread to them, was on the bridge, and, as his basket and stock in trade was seen floating in the canal, he may have been drowned.
The Coroner gave orders that the water should be let out of the canal, which was accomplished by 3 o'clock, when the bodies of two of the Federal soldiers, Geo. Ephart and Daniel LaRuke, of co. K, 30th Indiana, were recovered.
At the same time was recovered the body of a man in an advanced stage of decomposition, apparently a Georgia soldier who had been in the water for two months. The body was covered with mud and was not recognized.
Efforts will be made to-day to obtain the bodies of the other drowned parties, when Coroner Sanxay will hold an inquest on them.
In addition to those who lost their lives, two had their heads broken, two their arms, and minor bruises were inflicted on a number.
It may be as well to remark that the bridge, which had been in use for seven years, was made in Cincinnati and imported into Richmond.

div3.head: Complicated case of desertion and Substitution.
div3.p:
--On Monday evening, after considerable exertion, officers Folks and New, attached to the Assistant Provost Marshal's Office of the Eastern District, arrested a deserter from the 10th Louisiana Regiment, named Thomas Hunt, Hunt was also charged with selling himself as a substitute, after unceremoniously quitting his former companions in arms.
He had on his person when arrested a promissory note from Capt. A. J. Rodgers, of Rodgers's Cavalry Company, for $520--retained to ensure his attendance as a substitute member of that company; also, numerous other papers, among which was a British protection, in his own name, a certificate from Loftin N. Bilett, Clerk of the Confederate District Court, declaring his intention of becoming a citizen of the Confederate States, and that he was forty-five years old. This certificate was in the name of Thomas Conley.
Hunt, after leaving the 10th Louisiana regiment, went as a substitute for a man in company A. 44th Alabama regiment, from whom he received $1,675. The officers succeeded in recovering $1,370, which they turned over to Captain Morfeet, Ass't Q. M. C. S. A.; to be retained until the matter charged against Hunt shall be invested by Court-Martial.
Hunt, who is a stout Irishman, is only about 28 years of age. In his actions he is only one of a numerous class who have extensively victimized, not only parties buying substitutes, but the Government.

div3.head: Prison Items.
div3.p:
--The following parties were lodged in Castle Thunder yesterday as deserters, viz. Thos. Wilkinson, co. F. 53d Va reg't; E. A. Hearn, co C, 13th Miss and Thos. Hunt, co F, 45th Va. On the previous day twenty men were brought in charged with desertion.
Yesterday several of the inmates of the Castle were disposed of Robt Sadley, A Brown and J. B. Myers were sent to Camp Winder Hospital; and Edward Reagan and John Williams, alias John O'Neal, were delivered to Capt. Hawley, to whose company they belonged.

div3.head: Being Removed.
div3.p: --Workmen were engaged yesterday in removing the temporary railroad track on Broad street, laid down between the depots of the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac and Virginia Central railroads, some months since, to answer a military necessity.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
--Edward RcUormick was arraigned for presenting a loaded pistol at the heads of two watchmen who had spoken to him on Monday night for disorderly conduct.
This warlike manifestation was replied to by the watch by taking the belligerent party in custody, and marching him off to the cage.
The Mayor did not deem a state of semi-drunkenness any excuse for such reprehensible conduct, and therefore committed the defendant to await an indictment before the February Hustings Court Grand Jury.

The case of Daniel Dwyer, arrested for stealing a coat and counterpane from Timothy Trower, was called, when the defendant not responding to his name, a search was instituted, and it was found that he had escaped from the prisoner's box and gotten out of the Court room unperceived.
The police having the party in charge lucidly explained how the occurrence might have happened, whereupon his Honor adjourned its further investigation.

John and Hannah Murphy, husband and wife, were arraigned for fighting in the house of Cornolius Linnchan, and disturbing the public peace.
It appeared that Mrs. Murphy had struck Linnchan a blow.
The fight became general, when the police entered and marched off all hands to the cage.
Murphy and Mrs. Linnchan were deemed the most in fault, and falling to furnish security for their good behavior were sent to jail.

C. S. District Court.--This Court has been in session for several days.
No criminal case of importance has occupied the attention of the Court.
A number of decrees have been entered against parties holding the property of alien enemies, sequestrating the same to the use of the Confederate States.
The amount of property involved is quite large.
The Grand Jury having failed to find a true bill against John W. Williams, a soldier, held in custody on the charge of forgery, the Court directed his discharge from custody.
Charles A. Pittman, also a soldier, will be tried for forgery to-day.

div3.head: Another steamer in — interesting from Nassau
div3.p:
--Another large steamer freighted with coffee and other valuable merchandize, reached a Southern port this morning.
She brings Nassau dates to the 24th inst.

The steamship Leopard, from Charleston, had reached Nassau safely.
Nothing had been heard of the steamer Huntress, then overdue at Nassau.

The Bahama Herald reports, from a trustworthy source, that the commander of the British war steamer Callatin had received positive orders to capture Commodore Wilkes wherever be might be found, and convey him to Bermuda to be detained there until further orders; and that the British war steamer Vesuvius took on board at Mobile a million and a half of dollars, shipped by the British Consul.
Capt. Wilson, well known as the former commander of the ship Emily St. Pierre, is now in this city.

The steamer Havelook had The steamers Etcholas First, July, and U were still in port.
The steamers Annie Childs and Flars, the bark Mary Francis, and and had arrived at Nassau on the 13th and 14th, with assorted cargoes from British ports.
The Pride and Emma Tuttle had cleared for Baltimore.
The Clyde steamer Tonwald had been purchased by the Confederates.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p: --The Nassau Herald, of the 17th inst., says that the British ship Vesuvius, en route for England, took on board at Mobile one million five hundred thousand dollars, shipped by the British Consul at that port.

A Nassau letter reports the wreck off Abuse of the United States transport ship Planter, bound to New Orleans with 259 troops.
The vessel had proved a total wreck.
No lives were lost.
The United States Consul has chartered the ship Sallie Bounsall to take troops in New Orleans.
Duty declines the Federal Consulship at Nassau and Seth C. Hawley, of New York, has been appointed.

div3.head: Fort McAllister attacked by gunboats.
div3.p:
--Seven gunboats attacked Fort McAllister, at Gene Point, at 7 o'clock this morning.
The firing is still progressing at 11 A. M. The discharges are regular but very heavy.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--After five and a half hours fierce bombardment of Fort McAllister, the enemy withdrew about 1 o'clock this afternoon.
Not a man hurt nor a gun dismounted on our the damage to the fort can be repaired in a day.

div3.head: Successful Dash of Morgan's Cavalry.
div3.p:
--A special dispatch to the, Constitutionalist dated McMinnville, Tenn., 26th, says Morgan made a date into Weedbury this morning.
The Yankees stampeded, and we have hold the town.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 24, page 2.

div3.head: The North Revealed.
div3.p:
This war has indeed made some remarkable revelations.
It has lifted the veil from human nature, and let in a light upon its dark places like the searching blaze of the Day of Judgment.
The surface civilization of the age has been stripped from its enclosures, and displayed beneath the same evil passions which the inspired records teach us are characteristics of the heart of man beyond the power of any human agency to change.
The world, and especially the American part of it, has been exulting in the delusion of human perfect ability, and pointing, in proof of it to the progress of man in humanity since former ages.
But a few years ago it was even doubted whether wars would not soon come to an end. We believe it was Victor Huge who declared, in a speech at the Peace Congress in Paris, that a cannon would one day become a great curiosities, and exhibited with other curiosities in the museums of the Old World as a relic of the ancient barbarism of mankind.
But the dreams of the amiable enthusiasts of peace were suddenly dissipated by the Crimean war, then by the Indian mutiny, then by the Italian war, and lastly by the bloody convulsions in America, which have scattered to the winds the visions of dreaming philosophers.
The veneering of civilization has been rudely torn from the real character of man. It has proved but the velvet covering over the claws of the tiger.
The genuine instincts of the brute are all aroused by the sight of blood, and he at once begins to fight, in the language of the Gorilla, "with gloves off." In no part of the world and no period of its history has this been more manifest than in the external transformation which the North has undergone in this war. If any one ten or even five years ago had predicted that the Northern people would have made such a display of themselves as we have witnessed since the inauguration of Lincoln, he would have been laughed at as an idiot or a mad man. If one of their old worthies had risen from the dead and told them of the future, they would have exclaimed, as one man, "Is thy servant a dog, that he should do this thing?"

It was the hand of Bible Societies, of Tract Societies, of Peace Societies, of Christian Associations-- to say nothing of steam, gas, electricity, and commerce, which John Mitchell tells us are the osseous of modern civilization.
From its lofty religious and moral character, It looked down with the complacent spirit of genuine Pharisaism upon the benighted millions of the old world and the publicans and sinners of the Southern States.
In everything that pertained to the outside of the humanities it was perfect.
Its very linen had an air of sanctimony about it, and the physiognomies of its saints were white placid, and solemn as the tombs of the ancient Jews.
But the war has taught us what we might have long ago learned from Revelation, that ostentations pretenders to piety are 'whitaned sepulchres full of dead men's bones,' and that civilization, so called, has no more effect in altering the real nature of man than the moonbeams, which glitter upon a placid ocean, in changing the qualities of the sea. Never have a people so shamelessly cast askle all regard to honor, truth, humanity, common decency, as the Puritanical and civilized North in this unparalleled war.

div3.head: Public sentiment Abroad.
div3.p:
In holding up to last censure the unfriendly course of the English Government towards the Confederate States we should be careful to discriminate between the Government and the People.
The sympathy of intelligent Englishmen, outside of the narrow and bigoted pale of the Palmersion Administration, is almost universal with the South.
This sympathy has been practically manifested in every manner which their opportunities afforded.
It has shown itself in the public press, the greater portion of the respectable newspapers siding ably and energetically with the South.
It has been seen in the co-operation of private enterprise with the Southern Government in furnishing arms, ships, and seamen.
Not only the Alabama and her splendid armaments are of British manufacture, but most of her crew are thoroughbred British seamen.
If the public opinion of England had not been with us, none of the facilities which have been afforded as for carrying on the war could have been obtained.
We should be careful not to confound the generous and gallant majority of the English people with the short-sighted and illiberal clique of Palmersion and Russell.
If we have not received from the English Government what we had a right to expect, we have obtained bests of friends among the people, on whom we had no reason to calculate.--Before the war the South had scarcely a friend in the Old World.
Now, the elite of all Christendom is arrayed on its side, and in the end will make its influence felt directly as well as indirectly.
We make these remarks from no disposition to extenuate the unfair and selfish policy of European Governments.
But let us always keep distinct and separate the policy of their Governments and the sentiments of their people.
Let us not confound our friends with our enemies.
If the Governments of the Old World were as directly swayed by public sentiment as in Republics, the recognition of Southern Independence would take place without delay.
Let us be just, patient, and forbearing.

div3.head: Lincoln and number one.
div3.p:
The great burthen of Lincoln's letter to McClellan, when on the Peninsula, which has been lately published in this paper, is the vast and over shadowing importance of keeping Washington protected.
The gorilla announce it as one of the principles of this warfare that Washington must not be left uncovered.
It is the second, third, fourth, and fifth principles also, that no chance must be afforded to the rebels to make a break into Washington.
The unhappy creature whom the Yankees have made President never tires of reiterating the grand military axiom that, in all progressive and onward movements, anxious as he is for them, a sufficient force judged to be sufficient by all the military leaders must be left for the defence of Lincoln' Reward, and Company.
Whilst he devotes multitudes to death with the most supreme indifference, his whole soul is absorbed in the security of his own miserable carcase from the possibility of harm.
Was there ever such a contemptible monster?
No tyrant of Europe would refuse in his circumstances, to share the perils of his soldiery and lead them to the battle-field.
But Lincoln, as cowardly as he is cruel, is solicitous only that his own ungainly bones may be kept from grief!
Only imagine the President of the Confederate States inditing such a missive to Gen. Lee as that of Lincoln to McClellan.

It would be some compensation for the sorrows and tragedies of this dismal war if the Confederates could make a rush into Washington while the Black Republican Cabinet and Congress were both in session.
Only imagine Stuart's cavalry dashing through Pennsylvania Avenue, one division making for the White House and the other for the Capitol.
Think of their fiery sabre flashing into the eyes of Lincoln, Seward, Wade, Wilson, Chase & Co.--But they would never get close enough to them for that exhibition.
The fastest horses of Stuart's command could never outstrip the long legs of Lincoln and his Black Republicans.
Pitiful poltroons! Will Justice never overtake them?

div3.head: Department of East Tennessee.
div3.p:
--The Knoxville Register; states that Brigadier General Daniel H. Donelson will succeed Lieut.-General Kirby Smith, in command of the Department of East Tennessee.
His headquarters will probably be fixed at Chattanooga, since, as I am advised his department will embrace not only East.
Tennessee and Southwestern Virginia, but all of that portion of Middle Tennessee within our lines.
Gen. Donelson is in graduate of West Point.

div4.p: In Manchester, on the 16th inst., Mrs. Elizabeth Vest, in the 83d year of her age.
She died as she had lived, a Christian.

lg.l: Dearest mother, thou hast left us;
We thy loss most deeply feel,
But 'tis God that hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.
But again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life is fled;
Then in heaven with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell tear is shed.

div4.p: Her funeral will take place from the residence of her son-in-law, John Perry, this evening at 3 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are requested to attend without further notice. *
On the 27th inst., Josephine Lea, youngest daughter of Isaac J. and Josephine V. Mercer, aged 2 years 9 months and 6 days.

Her funeral will take place this morning, Jan'y 23th, at 11 o'clock, from the residence of her father, corner of 7th and Clay sts. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend without further notice. *
On Tuesday morning, Jan'y 27th, Eulalia, infant daughter of Thos W. and E. A Tignor, aged 1 year and 14 days.

Her funeral will take place from her father's residence, corner of Broad and 21st sts, at 3 o'clock this evening.
The relatives and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *
Yesterday, after a long and painful illness, Jno O Neill, In the 28th years of his age.
His funeral will take place from 8th Peter's Church this afternoon at 3 o'clock. His friends and acquaintances are respectfully requested to attend. *

In this city, on Saturday, January 24th, of congestive scarlet fever, after an illness of thirty hours Loyall, only child of Lizzie L and Commander John K Mitchell, C S N, aged 4 years 1 month and 10 days. *

On the 26th instant, at the city hospital, James Dodson.
Should any of his friends wish any information concerning him, apply at the hospital, near the aims-house. *

div3.p:

Private Clary is 45 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches in height, light hair, fair complexion, and blue eyes.
The above men were substitutes, and besides the above reward.
$80 each will be paid if delivered at Battery No. 8, or either of the Assistant Provost Marshals.

div3.head: Fortune for $5,00
div3.p:

The materials are so cheap that an outlay of $5,00 on one of the Recipes alone will realize $75 when manufactured and sold.
Any one can manufacture either article in an hour.
Written directions sent.

div3.head: Fifty dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from the subscriber, about two weeks ago, a negro boy named Henry.
Said boy is about sixteen years old, five feet high, round face, and good teeth; no doubt will say he is free; has been seen in Richmond in the last few days.
He may have gone to the army.
I will pay the above reward of fifty dollars for his delivery in any jail in the State.
